awd_titl_txt: Ecological Dynamics of the Plant-Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungal Mutualism: Contribution to Plant Species Turnover and Coexistence
awd_abstract_narration:
The iconic tallgrass prairie of the American heartland undergoes a constant process of renewal following fire and grazing.  The renewal consists of a turnover of species that provides for long-term coexistence and the maintenance of diversity.  Recently, it has been revealed that a type of fungus that penetrates that roots of prairie plants plays an important role in how they compete for resources, and these interactions differ among species.  The fungi thus affect how the sequence of turnover takes place.  The details of this interaction, and whether it helps some species and hinders others, is yet unknown.  This project will determine how this interaction affects the renewal process in unprecedented detail.  This research will aid in efforts to restore natural prairie communities in the Midwest.  Additionally, the project will provide training opportunities for students and contribute to a high school teacher development program.

A growing body of work has identified important roles of soil organisms in plant species coexistence and turnover during succession. Insight into the potential dynamics of these systems is limited by a poor understanding of soil organism dynamics. This gap will be addressed in observational, experimental, and modeling stages.  Observations will span time and space in monitoring changes in arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal composition and plant growth across multiple plant species of varying life history.  The dynamics of plant populations resulting from these fungal changes will be examined. Manipulative experiments will be designed and conducted to differentiate and quantify the impact of allocation of resources by the hosts to preferred mycorrhizae from fungal competitive ability. A conceptual model, including simulation, will be developed to produce a new theoretical framework that integrates plant physiological plasticity and life history trade-offs with plant-arbuscular mycorrhizal community feedbacks.

por.por_cntn:
Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi facilitate resource uptake of most plant species. We found that the presence, composition and diversity of AM fungi can have large effects on plant communities.  We assessed the dynamics of AM fungi and the resulting feedbacks on plant growth using multiple approaches, including mesocosm assays, floral surveys, field inoculations, and theory development. 

 

Plant phylogeny influenced AM fungal composition, but not mycorrhizal feedback.

Phylosymbiosis, i.e. the host phylogenetic constraints on symbiont composition, has often been interpreted as host-symbiont co-evolution, in which hosts differentially benefit from their coevolved symbionts. We tested whether influence of host evolutionary history on symbiont composition translates into stronger mutualistic benefits. We observed significant phylosymbiosis in Arbuscular Mycorrhizal (AM) fungi within constructed microbiomes composed of isolates derived from tallgrass prairie, grown with 38 grassland plant species. While AM fungi overwhelming improved growth of these plant species, phylogenetic structure of AM fungal genotypes and species generally fails to translate to improved benefit to their host. Pairwise mycorrhizal feedback ranged from significantly positive to significantly negative, and strength of mycorrhizal feedback was not significantly predicted by phylogenetic distance between plant hosts, counter to common expectations from observations of phylosymbiosis. 

 

AM fungal dynamics mediate plant succession.

We found that late successional prairie plant species are more dependent on AM fungi and are more sensitive in their responses to AM fungal identity. We also found that AM fungal community structure and genetic composition differed significantly between mesocosms hosted by early vs late successional plant hosts. Resulting mycorrhizal feedback between early and late successional species were generally positive, as expected from our observation of late successional species have greater ability to preferentially allocate to the most effective AM fungal species. We developed theory showing that these positive AM fungal feedbacks can mediate plant species turnover, potentially accelerating, or impeding succession.

 

Phosphorus fertilization alters AM fungal composition and function.

Fertilization is a widespread practice with the potential to degrade AM fungal communities. We found that phosphorus fertilization reduced allocation to beneficial AM fungi, thereby favoring non-beneficial AMF. Fertilization altered the AM fungal community and genetic composition in mesocosms and in the field.  More beneficial AM fungal species declined when exposed to elevated phosphorus. The impact of phosphorus on AM fungal composition depended on plant life history with the most beneficial AM fungal taxa showing a stronger decline with phosphorus when raised on a late successional plant host.  Early successional plant hosts in high phosphorus environment, resulted in AM fungal communities with greater ability to infect roots, though not necessarily more beneficial, consistent with the spread of weedy fungi.

 

Dispersal-limitation of AM fungi limits establishment of plants on islands.

For most species of AM fungi dispersal is limited to hyphal growth—i.e. very local. We measured dispersal of inoculated AM fungi on the scale of meters in grasslands.  We find evidence AM fungal dispersal limits host colonization of oceanic islands, as plants that do not associate with mycorrhizal fungi are overrepresented on floras of oceanic islands, while plants that associate with AM fungi are underrepresented compared to mainland floras. These differences increased with distance from the mainland. This mycorrhizal filter on island colonization is replicated with N-fixing and pollination mutualisms, and these mutualist filters are strongest in the tropics.  Finally, we find that non-native plants from mainlands are more likely to associate with AM fungi than expected, consistent with agricultural and horticultural plants being brought to islands with infected roots, opposite the pattern on mainlands.

 

Native AM fungi promote native grassland restoration.

            We found that native prairie AM fungi have limited natural recolonization following agricultural disturbance.  Reintroduction of native prairie AM fungi consistently enhanced the success of late successional plants within prairie restorations, thereby resulting in greater native diversity and suppression of non-native and undesirable weeds. Benefits of inoculation increased over time, consistent with positive mycorrhizal feedbacks. Local dispersal of native AM fungi can lead to expansion of patches of late successional prairie plants through nucleation dynamics.

 

Broader impacts.

We trained six postdocs (five of whom are currently professors or research scientists), six grad students (four of whom are currently postdocs), five technicians (all of whom moved to permanent positions), and many undergrads. An INTERN supplement supported a graduate student training with Kansas Nature Conservancy. A Postbac supplement supported a scholar’s research who is currently in grad school at Ohio State. We supported Next Generation Science standards through implementing education modules in local elementary schools. We taught in four local ecology summer workshops for 6-12 teachers and developed and implemented a test of local plant adaptation in 4 KS high schools. A RET supplement supported one of these teachers to analyze this data and write a manuscript that was published in a peer reviewed journal. We gave ten talks to non-scientific audiences, including at art museums, libraries, and master gardener associations.
